lines.text: Well, I can understand how you feel. You worked hard, studying for the spelling bee, and I suppose you feel you let everyone down, and you made a fool of yourself and everything. But did you notice something, Charlie Brown?
What's that?
The world didn't come to an end.
[at the spelling bee]
Fussbudget, F-U-S-S-B-U-D-G-E-T, Fussbudget.
[the Peanuts gang watching the spelling bee on TV]
Hey! How'd he know that word?

[thinking]
Well, we lost the first game of the season again. I know it shouldn't bother me, but it does. We always seem to lose the first game of the season and the last game of the season.
[pause, then yells to the sky]
And all those stupid games in between!

[about Schroeder's Beethoven bust statue]
Incidentally, who's this? George Washington?
I'm dying, and all I hear are insults!
[last line of the movie]
Welcome home, Charlie Brown.
[Lucy shuts the TV off after Charlie Brown lost the spelling bee]

[angrily]
Owning 10% of Charlie Brown is like owning 10% of nothing!
[turns the TV on again]
Charlie Brown, you - you make me mad!
[shuts the TV off again]
[first lines]

Aren't the clouds beautiful? They look like big balls of cotton. I could just lie here all day and watch them drift by. If you use your imagination, you can see lots of things in the cloud's formations. What do you think you see, Linus?
Well, those clouds up there look to me look like the map of the British Honduras on the Caribbean.
[points up]
That cloud up there looks a little like the profile of Thomas Eakins, the famous painter and sculptor. And that group of clouds over there...
[points]
...gives me the impression of the Stoning of Stephen. I can see the Apostle Paul standing there to one side.
Uh huh. That's very good. What do you see in the clouds, Charlie Brown?
Well... I was going to say I saw a duckie and a horsie, but I changed my mind.
You know, Charlie Brown, they say we learn more from losing than from winning.
Then that must make me the smartest person in the world.
Life is difficult, isn't it, Charlie Brown?
Yes, it is. But I've developed a new philosophy. I only dread one day at a time.

[Walks into Linus's bedroom and raises the shade]
Wake up Linus. It's time to go to school.
Again?
What do you mean 'again'?

[Snuggles back into bed]
I went yesterday.
Mom's already made your lunch.
[Sets it on his bed and walks out]

[Sits up in bed, sighs]
Guess I might as well go to school. I can't waste a good lunch.
Don't be discouraged, Charlie Brown. You have nothing to lose. You'll either be the hero, or a goat.
[Snoopy, who is standing next to him, bleats like a goat, then walks away]
Here, run over to the drinking fountain and soak this handkerchief in cold water.
[Lucy skeptically examines the handkerchief]
You're kidding. With a head like Charlie Brown's, you'll need a bedsheet.
I'm dying! And all I hear are insults!
This pitcher's mound is covered with dandelions!
Don't touch them Charlie Brown! Don't you dare hurt all those innocent dandelions! They're beautiful! Don't you dare cut them down!
Besides... you may not know this, but you look kind of cute standing there surrounded by dandelions.
I don't want to look cute!
I've never gone through anything like that in my life. I never knew I could be so stupid. I never knew I had so many faults. I never felt so completely miserable.
Wait until you get my bill.

[At the bus stop returning home]
I guess nobody realized that we were returning.

[At the bus stop departing for the national spelling bee]
This whole thing makes me feel as though I'm being drafted.
Alright, Charlie Brown, let's get our signals straight. One finger will mean the high straight ball, and two fingers will mean the low straight ball.
What about my curveball? And my slider? And my knuckleball? And my sidearm? And my submarine pitch?
One finger will mean the high straight ball, and two fingers will mean the low straight ball.
[Charlie Brown grimaces]
Why can't I have an ordinary dog like everyone else?
Does anyone here know first aid?
It's probably not serious. Second or third aid will do.
My blanket... I can't be without it!
You must learn how to smile, Charlie Brown. Smile!
[Charlie Brown smiles; Snoopy smiles more broadly; Lucy compares the two]
You've got a smile like a sick pumpkin.
You look like you've been through shock treatment or something.
What's more shocking than having your faults projected on a screen?
These slides show your tendency toward fatness.
[Next slide]
Look at that stomach!
[Next slide]
Even your nose is fat, and your legs. Why, I bet if the truth were known, even your toes are fat.
This blanket is a necessity. It keeps me from cracking up. It may be regarded as a spiritual tourniquet. Without it, I'd be nothing, a ship without a rudder.
I think these psychiatrist visits are gonna bankrupt me.
